metadata.title: Artificial neural network modelling of amido black dye sorption on iron composite nano material: Kinetics and thermodynamics studies

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Artificial neural network modelling of amido black dye sorption on iron composite nano material: Kinetics and thermodynamics studies
Imran Ali a,e,⁎, Omar M.L. Alharbi b, Zeid A. Alothman c, Ahmad Yacine Badjah c, Abdulrahman Alwarthan c, Al Arsh Basheer d
a Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Taibah University, Al-Medina Al-Munawara, 41477, Saudi Arabia b Biology Department, Faculty of Sciences, Taibah University, Al-Medina Al-Munawara, 41477, Saudi Arabia c Department of Chemistry, College of Science, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia d State University of New York, Flint Entrance, Amherst, NY 14260, Buffalo, USA e Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia, (Central University), New Delhi, India
⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistr University, Al-Medinah Al-Munawarah, 41477, Saudi Arab
E-mail addresses: drimran_ali@yahoo.com, drimran.ch
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2017.11.163 0167-7322/© 2017 Published by Elsevier B.V.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 7 November 2017 Received in revised form 24 November 2017 Accepted 27 November 2017 Available online 28 November 2017
The sorption of amido black dye inwater on iron composite nanomaterial is defined in batch process optimizing starting amido black amount, agitation time, pH, nanomartial dose, and temp. The sorption results compliedwith Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin andDubinin-Radushkevich facsimilia. The proposed iron composite nanomaterial were suitable for the sorption of amido black in water with determined 88%. The uptake was impulsive and exothermic. The adjusted batch limits were initial concentration 100 μg/L; agitation time 25min, pH 7.0, dose 1.0 g/L and 25 °C temperature. The thermodynamic parameters like ΔG°, ΔH° and ΔS° were −8.14, −8.10 and −8.02 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temps; −4.32 kJ/mol and −9.30 × 10−3 kJ/mol K. The pseudo-first-order and liquid-film-diffusion mechanistic of the sorption were projected. The proposed sorption process was quick, ecological responsive and low-priced as may be utilized in normal water conditions. The artificial neural network modelling confirmed the applicability of the developed method. The method was competent to grind at normal water assets pHs with low sorbent amount and agitate time. The sorption process may be practical for the elimination of amido black dye from some water assets at large and low-priced scale.
© 2017 Published by Elsevier B.V.
Keywords: Adsorption Amido black dye Kinetics Artificial neural network Thermodynamics Modelling

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The dyed industrialized effluents release from a number of industries is stern matter of concern in water pollution. The majority of dyed industrialized effluents release factories are leather, textile, printing, paper, cosmetics, sugar, food and some drugs manufacturing. The dyed water stops the entry of natural radiations to the base of water bodies (lakes, river and ponds). This results in inhibition of photosynthesis in plants. This also results in the production of anaerobic situation, which is lethal for the flora and fauna [1]. Amido black dye is an amino acid stain diazo dye. It is applied in biochemical studies to dye different proteins in various biological fluids. It is applied in criminal testing to determine blood on fingerprints. It is also used to test handwritings, inks, papers, fibers, hairs, and paints. In industries, this dye is used for coloring natural fibers (wool and cotton) and synthetics
y, College of Sciences, Taibah ia. iral@gmail.com (I. Ali).
polymers. This is also applied in the plastics, ink, paint, and fleece manufacturing [2–5]. This dye is highly toxic as damages respiratory system. Besides, this dye also origin of eye and skin annoyances [2]. The chemical name of amido black dye is 4-amino-5-hydroxy-3[(4-nitrophenyl)azo]-6-(phenylazo)-2,7-naphthalene disulfonic acid, disodium salt (Fig. 1).
Due to the toxic nature of amido black dye, it is necessary to expand effective, rapid, low-priced and elective removal process for this toxic dye. Some papers describe the removal of this toxic dye using adsorption and degradation methods [6,7]. The microbe degradation of dyes is not recommended due to secondary contamination of water. The described adsorption processes are not effectual as most of them are not competent to take away amido black at normal situation of water, especially pH and temp. Also, the photo-degradation products may be poisonous. The artificial neural network (ANN) is considered as single mainly imperative predicting means for the sorption phenomenon [7]. It has been used by a number of workers to predict the adsorption from [8–11]. Consequently, an ANN basedmodel was built up in this research for relating the sorption. Due to these facts, adsorption is believed as single process for water handling [12–15]. Consequently, the
endeavors were made for the elimination of amido black dye in water exploiting iron nano composite material.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text: A.R. grades chemicals and reagents were used in this research. Amido black dye was gained from Sigma Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). Millipore water was prepared from Millipore-Q, Bedford, MA, USA system. Iron composite nanomaterialwas prepared and distinguished as illustrated somewhere else [16,17].

sections.heading: 2.2. Instruments
sections.text: The research was conceded out on thermostatic water bath shaker. The dissimilar concerns. of amido black were ascertained at 620 nm λmax using UV–Visb. Spectrometer (model T 80) PG Instruments Ltd., UK. Additional instruments used were sonicator, centrifuge machine, weighing balance and digital pH meter.

sections.heading: 2.3. Uptake of amido black dye
sections.text:
The bulk solution of amido black (1.0 mg/L) was arranged in Millipore water. In addition, the required dilutions were done as per the rations (10–200 μg/L). The batch uptake experimentationswere finished at fixed stir time. The subsequent experimentation constraints were diversified to get hold of the highest elimination of amido black.
1. Amido black concen. 2. Contact time. 3. Dose. 4. Dye solution pH. 5. Temperature. Adsorbent (fixed amount) was to solution of amido black dye (10 mL) of changeable concentrations in 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks. These flasks were stimulated incessantly in water bath shaker at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperature. The solutionswere taken out and centrifuged after certain determined time intervals. The concentrations of dye were ascertained spectrometrically. The adsorption was done at fixed dose and dissimilar concerns. and temps. for kinetic purpose. For adsorption isotherms, the experiment were done at 5–35 min contact time, 0.1– 1.5 g/L dose, 25–200 μg/L conc., 3–9 pHs and 20.0–30.0 °C temps. The experimentations were done at 5 times (n = 5). Amount of the dye up taken per unit mass (qe, mg/g) was premeditated utilizing the equation given below.
qe ¼ Co−Ceð Þ=m ð1Þ
where, Co = original conc. of amido black (μg/L), Ce = equilibrium concentrations of amido black (μg/L) andm=quantity of the adsorbent (g/L).
Percentage adsorption was calculated using equation given below.
%adsorption ¼ 100 Co−Ceð Þ=Co ð2Þ
2.4. Artificial neural network model
Basically, ANN architecture comprises input layers (independent variables), hidden layers and output layers (dependent variables). Each layer has a number of interconnected processing units (neurons). All the neurons are connected to each other in thepreceding and following layer by links system. The input layer gets information from outside resources and bypasses to the hidden layer for dealing out. Prior to ingoing the hidden layer, the input values are weighted independently and the all the data processing is done by the hidden layer; resulting into generation of output supported on the total the weighted magnitudes from the input layer adapted by a sigmoid transfer function [18,19]. The contact time, temp., pH, dye concen. and the quantity of nanosorbent were considered as input data for the model. The sorption effectiveness data were place in and considered as output. The data was separated into three classes of training, validation and testing. 60, 20 and 20% datawere applied for training, validation and testing. The numbers of neurons were 5, 8 and 1 in the input and hidden and output layers, respectively. The network structure with the three layers is shown in Fig. 2. The network presentation was estimated based to experimental data fitness and the forecast accuracy of the model utilized. Mean Square Error (MSE) was measured using following equation.
MSE ¼ P qexp−qcal =qexp
100 N
ð3Þ
where, qexp, qcal and N were the experimental amount, calculated amount adsorbed and number of variables.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: The adsorption of the reported dye was fixed by the different variables. These variables include concentration of amido black dye, time of contact, adsorbent dose, dye solution pH and temperature. The variation of these parameters is discussed in subsequent headings.

sections.heading: 3.1. Amido black concentration
sections.text: The concentration result of removal of amido black was studied using various concentrations (10 to 200 μg/L) while the other variables were constant i.e. contact time 30min, pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and temperature 25 °C. The uptake of amido black ranged from 88 to 100%. It was 100% (2.0 μg/g), 95% (4.75 μg/g), 92% (9.20 μg/g) and 88% (17.6 μg/g) at 10, 25, 50 and 100 μg/L concentrations (Fig. 3a). It was steady at elevated conc. of amido black. It is obviously exhibited that the uptakewas reliant on the starting conc. of amido black. It might be owing to the open obtainable viable surface area on adsorbent at little conc., which reduced as the conc. of the amido black augmented. It is significant to state that quantity at equilibrium (qe) enlarged as the percentage reduced. It was owing to the reality that at elevated conc. huge amount of amido blackmolecules absorbed the adsorbent surface, leading to uptake of elevated figure of amido blackmolecules. As a result, the highest molecular adsorption of amido black was achieved at 100 μg/g conc. in the described experimentation circumstances.

sections.heading: 3.2. Equilibrium time
sections.text: The batch adsorption experimentswere carried out during 5–35min by making other parameters constant i.e. initial concentration 100 μg/L, pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and temp. 25 °C. This affect is shown in Fig. 3b. It is apparent from this Figure that uptake of the amido black augmented from 5.0 to 30.0 min, that had become steady on additional rising of contact time. The maximum uptake of the amido black at 30 min was 17.6 μg/L (88%). Therefore, 30 min shaking time was preferred as the best one.

sections.heading: 3.3. pH
sections.text: The batch adsorption experiments for the amido black were carried out from 3.0 to 9.0 pH by making other parameters constant i.e. contact time30min, dose 0.5 g/L initial concentration 100 μg/L, 7.0, and temperature 25 °C. This affect is shown in Fig. 3c. It is seeming from this Figure that at first sorption of the amido black was 3.0 μg/g which increased to 17.6 μg/g at pH 7.0. Also the sorption increased by augmenting pH (8 and 9). At high pH the sulfoyl groups of the amido black exited as anions, ensuing to elevated sorption. However, it was ineffective as many of water spring do not contain these pH values.

sections.heading: 3.4. Dose
sections.text: The batch adsorption experiments for the amido blackwere conceded from 0.1 to 1.5 g/L doses by making other parameters constant i.e. pH 7.0, contact time 30 min, starting concentration 100 μg/L, and temperature 25 °C. This affect is shown in Fig. 3d. It is seeming from this Figure that the uptake of the amido black augmented from 0.1 and 0.50 g/L dose (10 to 88%). It was owing to good ease of access of the sorbent surface sites at elevated dose. Further augment in the dose of (1.0 and 1.5 g/L) could not result in additional sorption. It was owing to all the surface area of 0.5 g/L dose was enough for uptake of amido black (150 μg/L conc.).

sections.heading: 3.5. Temperature
sections.text:
The batch adsorption experiments for the amido blackwere conceded from 20, 25 and 30 °C temperature bymaking other parameters constant i.e. contact time 30 min, dose 0.5 g/L initial conc. 100 μg/L, and pH 7.0. This affect is shown in Fig. 3e. It is seeming from this Figure that sorptionwas equivalent up to 50 μg/L concentration for all the temperatures (20, 25 and 30 °C). However it varied by augmenting the temperature. It was in the order of 20 N 25 N 30 °C. Keeping these points into consideration, the sorption was assumed to be exothermic. It might be owing to the augment in the speed of diffusion of amido black diagonally the external border layer.
3.6. Artificial neural network model
The consequences of ANN model were comparing with experimentations values. The contact of eachfive variables on the sorption efficiency was evaluated. The values obtained by modelling were in good agreement with those obtained experimentally. The values of the relative error obtained by ANN are graphed in Fig. 4. This is obvious from
this Figure that the magnitudes of relative errors were in the range of ±0.1 to 4.0. Therefore, the network was considered as applicable to the sorption studies of amido black.

sections.heading: 3.7. Modelling of molecular uptake of amido black
sections.text: The sorption data was handled using various models, which included Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, and Dubinin-Radushkevich. The outcome of the molecular sorption of the amido black was reported. The sorption of the amido black was studied at three temps. of 20, 25, 30 °C. The equations of the models are as below:

sections.heading: 3.7.1. Langmuir
sections.text: 1=Q t ¼ 1=XmbCt þ 1=Xm ð4Þ

sections.heading: 3.7.2. Separation factor (RL)
sections.text: RL ¼ 1= 1þ bCeð Þ ð5Þ

sections.heading: 3.7.3. Freundlich
sections.text: logQ t ¼ 1=nð Þ logCt þ logkF ð6Þ

sections.heading: 3.7.4. Temkin
sections.text: Q t ¼ RT=BTð Þ ln Ct þ RT=BTð ÞlnKT ð7Þ

sections.heading: 3.7.5. Dubinin-Radushkevich
sections.text:
lnQ t ¼ lnqm−βε2 ð8Þ
ε ¼ RTln 1þ 1=Ctð Þ ð9Þ
E ¼ 1=√ −2βð Þ ð10Þ

sections.heading: 3.8. Langmuir model
sections.text:
The values of the different symbols in Langmuir model are – Qt = amount adsorbed of amido black at time t and Ct = concentration of amido black at time t. Xm (μg/g) and b (L/μg) are constants of Langmuir isotherm. Langmuir isotherms were constructed by plotting 1/Qt vs 1/Ct (Fig. 5a). The magnitudes of Xm and b were obtained by slope and intercept of the graph 1/Qt vs 1/Ct. The
data obeyed Langmuir isotherm and Langmuir constants values are briefed in Table 1. The values established the submission of Langmuir model. The values of b constant were 0.17, 0.16 and 0.15 at 20, 25, 30 °C temp. while the values of Xm were 28.32, 26.38 and 24.21 at these temp. The magnitude of dimensionless constants were 0.62, 0.59 and 0.56 at 20, 25, 30 °C temperature. The values of R2 were 0.989, 0.993 and, 0.996 at three temperatures, separately and respectively.

sections.heading: 3.9. Freundlich model
sections.text:
The values of the different symbols in Freundlich model are – kF [(μg/g)] and n are coefficients of Freundlich. These belong to comparative uptake intensities and capacities. Freundlich model was constructed by plotting logQt vs logCt (Fig. 5b). 1/n and kF correspond to slope and intercept of graph of logQt vs logCt. The calculated values of n and kF are summarized in
Table 1. It is apparent from this table that values of kF were 2.78, 2.85 and 2.94 at 20, 25, 30 °C temp. On the other hand, the values of n were 1.19, 1.29 and 1.43 at these temp. The magnitudes of R2 were 0.911, 0.901 and, 0.881 at three temperature, separately and respectively. Furthermore, a look on these values confirmed low uptake of the amido black at elevated temperature. These values apparently established the submission of Freundlich model to the sorption data of the amido black.
d): Dubinin-Radushkevich isotherms for the removal of amido black dye.
Table 1 Isotherm parameters values for amido black.
Temps. Langmuir isotherm Freundlich isotherm Temkin isotherm Dubinin-Radushkevich
Xm (μg/g) b (L/μg) RL R2 kF (μg/g) n (μg/L) R2 KT (L/μg) BT(kJ/mol) R2 qm (μg/g E kJ/mol R2
20 °C 28.32 0.15 0.62 0.989 2.783 1.19 0.911 1.1814 0.165 0.960 19.03 0.70 0.945 25 °C 26.38 0.17 0.59 0.993 2.847 1.29 0.901 1.1198 0.182 0.975 18.56 0.71 0.958 30 °C 24.21 0.19 0.56 0.996 2.939 1.43 0.881 1.0313 0.208 0.986 17.56 0.72 0.972

sections.heading: 3.10. Temkin model
sections.text: The values of the different symbols in Temkin model are – KT (L/g) = the maximum binding energy and BT (kJ/mol) = heat of sorption. Tempkinmodel was constructed usingQt vs log Ce (Fig. 5c). The constant BT and KT were approximated from slope and intercept of Fig. 5c. Values of KT were 1.18, 1.12 and 1.03 at 20, 25, 30 °C temperature. On the other hand, the magnitudes of BT were 0.17, 0.18 and 0.21 at these temperatures, respectively. The values of R2 were 0.960, 0.975 and, 0.986 at three temperature, separately and respectively. Furhermore, it was observed that the values of KT and BT indicated a tiny alteration in the heat of molecular elimination of amido black and powerful interactions between nanoparticle and amido black.

sections.heading: 3.11. Dubinin-Radushkevich model
sections.text:
The values of the different symbols in Dubinin-Radushkevichmodel are –
E = average energy and qm = degree of molecular uptake of amido black per mole of dye.
Dubinin-Radushkevich model was constructed using ln Qt and E2 (Fig. 5d). The constants E and qm can be calculated by slop and intercept of Fig. 5d. The Emagnitudeswere varied from0.70 to 0.72 kJ/mol; investigative of physio-sorption. The values of qm were 19.03, 18.56 and 17.56 at 20, 25 and 30 °C temp. The values of R2 were 0.945, 0.958 and, 0.972 at three temperature. These values apparently established the submission of Dubinin-Radushkevich model to the sorption data of the amido black. The average relative errors in the regressions were determined. The values were in the range of 0.5 to 1.0. These values indicate a good applicability of the data.

sections.heading: 3.12. Thermodynamics of amido black sorption
sections.text:
For the calculation of the thermodynamics of the sorption of amido black free energy, enthalpy and entropy were determined. These values were ascertained by using the following equations.
G ° ¼ −RTlnQ ð11Þ
lnQ ° ¼ ΔS °=R−ΔH °=RT ð12Þ
where, R is a general gas constant; 0.008314 kJ/mol K−1; and T is an absolute temp. (K), and Q° = Langmuir constant.
ΔH° and ΔS° were calculated by a graph of lnQ° vs 1/T (not given in this article). The slop and intercept corresponded to ΔS° and ΔH°. The magnitudes of enthalpy, free energy, and entropy are summarized in Table 2. The magnitudes of free energy, enthalpy and entropy were (−)-ve, indicating spontaneous and exothermic sorption of amido
black. The average relative errors in the regressions were determined. The values were in the range of 0.51 to 1.0. These values indicate a good applicability of the data.

sections.heading: 3.13. Kinetics of amido black sorption
sections.text:
For the calculation of the kinetics of the sorption of amido black free pseudo first order kinetic, pseudo second order kinetic model and Elovich's kinetic models were used. These values were ascertained by using following equations.
3.13.1. Pseudo-first-order kinetic
log Qe–Q tð Þ ¼ logQe−k1 t=2:303 ð13Þ

sections.heading: 3.13.2. Pseudo-second order kinetic model
sections.text: t=Q t ¼ 1=hþ t=Qe ð14Þ

sections.heading: 3.13.3. Elovich's kinetic model
sections.text:
Q t ¼ 1=β ln αβð Þ þ 1=βlnt ð15Þ
The stability rate constant of sorption of amido black [k1 (min−1)] was ascertained by a slop of log(Qe–Qt) versus t graph (Fig. 6a). The values of pseudo first order rate coefficient and regression coefficient (R2) were 0.098 (min−1) and 0.947. These magnitudes established the suitability of pseudo first order equation. Values of theoretic and experimentationmagnitudes of the stability amounts of the sorption of amido black were 16.19 and 17.60 μg/g. The experimentation magnitude was 8.0% greater than the theoretical one. Hence, this conclusion was assumed as good fitting of pseudo first order model. All the same, pseudo second order kinetic model was tested the sorption data of the sorption of amido black. In beginning sorption of amido black rate constant (h) was ascertained by pseudo second order (Fig. 6b). k2 (rate constant) and Qe were ascertained by the intercept and slope the of t/Qt vs t plot. Themagnitude of k2 was lesser than the scale of h (Table 3). It predicted the speedy sorptionof amidoblack in the inaugurationwent after by sluggish uptake. Low amount of regression coefficient (R2) (0.987) also indicated not appropriate of pseudo-second order equation to amido black sorption. The % disparity between theoretical and experimentation magnitudes was 85.0%, high is high. This observation established non fitting of the pseudo second order kinetic equation. In winding up, the sorption of amido black data agreed the pseudo-first order kineticmodel. The eq. 14 used to ascertain uptake and desorption. α (μg/g/min) and β (g/μg) are uptake and desorption speed constants. For this, the magnitude of α and β were 4.13 and 0.17 (Table 3). The values established greater rate of the sorption of amido black than desorption. The values of regression constant (0.958), reflected good suitably of Elovich's kinetic model. The average relative errors in the regressions were determined. The values were in the range of 0.40 to 1.0. These values indicate a good applicability of the data.

sections.heading: 3.14. Mechanism of amido black sorption
sections.text: For the determination of mechanism of the sorption of amido black, intra-particle diffusion kinetic and liquid-film-diffusion kinetic models were used. These equations are given below.

sections.heading: 3.14.1. Intraparticle diffusion kinetic model
sections.text:
Qt ¼ kipdt05 ð16Þ
3.14.2. Liquid film diffusion kinetic model
ln 1−Fð Þ ¼ −kfdt ð17Þ
Liquid film diffusion kinetic model was constructed by plotting Qt vs t0.5. The eq. 15 (Qt vs t0.5) was used to determine the sorption of amido black. The rate constant of the sorption was 2.61 μgg−1 min−0.5. The intercept was 2.54. The regression constant was 0.919 (Table 3). It was seen that the graph line had not been passed by the source. It showed the no validity of intra-particle diffusion model. Film diffusion kinetic model was constructed by plotting t vs ln(1−F). Fractional achievement of equilibrium (F = Qt/Qe) and film diffusion speed constant (kfd) of the sorption of amido black were ascertained. The value of kfd was 0.125 and the value of intercept was 0.173. Value of regression coefficient was 0.955 (Table 3). It was observed that straight line of ln(1−F) vs t graph departed with 0.50, showing proximity to origin. It disappearance might be owing to soaring commotion in batch operations. The disparity among rates ofmass transfer in opening andpreceding phases was owing to the trouble in the experimentations. This sorts of divergences are also available in the various research publications [20–25]. Thus, the sorption of amido blackwas assumed to be controlled by liquid-film-diffusion mechanism.

sections.heading: 3.15. Regeneration of the sorbent
sections.text: The utility of a sorbent is determined by its regeneration and reuse. For this purpose, the sorbentwas regenerated and recycled. The sorbent was treated with bases, acids, and buffers solutions. The bases applied were potassium hydroxide and sodium hydroxide. The acids applied were HNO3, HCl, and H2SO4. The buffers tested were citrate, acetate, and phosphate, for this purpose. After wide range of experiments, it was seen that better reagent for regeneration was 11 mM hydrochloric acid. This renewed the sorbent up to 90%. The renewed sorbent was exploited for alternate six batch experimentations. The sorption of amido black capability ranged from 84 to 87%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The prepared and differentiated sorbent was found to be competent to adsorb of amido black in water with maximum 88%. The sorption of amido black was impulsive and exothermic. The fixed batch changeables were 100 μg/L conc.; 30 min. Contact time; 7.0 pH; 1.0 g/L dose and 25 °C temp. The sorption of amido black data shadowed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. Values of ΔG° were−8.14,−8.10 and−8.02 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures, respectively. The magnitudes of ΔH° and ΔS° were −4.32 kJ/mol and −9.32 × 10−3 kJ/mol K. The sorption of amido black was guarded by the pseudo first order and liquid-film diffusion mechanism. Reported method of sorption of amido black method was speedy, environmental receptive and logically priced. It was owing to its characteristics for application in standard water circumstances of the diverse water capital. The artificial neural network modelling confirmed the applicability of the developed method. The described sorption of amido black way is
competent to exertion at standardwater capital pHswith lower sorbent dose and contacting time. Hence, described sorption of amido black method can be concerned for the sorption of amido black from any water stuff at huge and lucrative levels.
